Article.Abstract: In the setting of acute hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection, robust HCV-specific CD8+ cytotoxic T lymphocyte (CTL) responses are associated with initial control of viremia. Despite these responses, 70-80% of individuals develop persistent infection. Although viral escape from CD8 responses has been illustrated in the chimpanzee model of HCV infection, the effect of CD8 selection pressure on viral evolution and containment in acute HCV infection in humans remains unclear. Here, we examined viral evolution in an immunodominant human histocompatibility leukocyte antigen (HLA)-B8-restricted NS3 epitope in subjects with acute HCV infection. Development of mutations within the epitope coincided with loss of strong ex vivo tetramer and interferon gamma enzyme-linked immunospot responses, and endogenous expression of variant NS3 sequences suggested that the selected mutations altered processing and presentation of the variant epitope. Analysis of NS3 sequences from 30 additional chronic HCV-infected subjects revealed a strong association between sequence variation within this region and expression of HLA-B8, supporting reproducible allele-specific selection pressures at the population level. Interestingly, transmission of an HLA-B8-associated escape mutation to an HLA-B8 negative subject resulted in rapid reversion of the mutation. Together, these data indicate that viral escape from CD8+ T cell responses occurs during human HCV infection and that acute immune selection pressure is of sufficient magnitude to influence HCV evolution.
Article.ArticleTitle: CD8 epitope escape and reversion in acute HCV infection.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: B-cells were transfected with mRNA derived from the acute prototype (genotype 1a HCV acute infected patient) and variant sequences to assess the impact of mutations on processing and presentation of epitope. This prototype sequence gave 16% CD8 tet+ cells releasing IFN-γ.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Subject designated 99B was innoculated by needle stick. Subject designated 02J was innoculated in unknown manner. Subject designated 02K was innoculated by tranfusion recipient from patient designated 02J from this same study.
Subject designated 99B was innoculated by needle stick. Subject designated 02J was innoculated in unknown manner.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: A CTL escape experiment was performed demonstrating CD8+ T cell population responsiveness to epitope using B8-1395 tetramer staining over the course of 86 weeks. All B8 responses declined by the end of the testing period.

The impact of variant peptides in a cytotoxicity assay was determined. Fixed variants from later time points of patient 99B and 02J of this study did not have any substantial impact on cytotoxicity compared with the wild-type sequence.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: HLA-B8 restricted epitope. This is a naturally occuring variant identified in HCV patient with acute stage of disease after primary CD8+ response.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: B-cells were transfected with mRNA derived from the acute prototype (genotype 1a HCV acute infected patient) and variant sequences to assess the impact of mutations on processing and presentation of epitope. This variant sequence gave 17.9% CD8 tet+ cells releasing IFN-γ compared to acute prototype sequence which gave 16%.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: HLA-B8 restricted epitope. This is a naturally occuring variant identified in HCV patient with acute stage of disease after primary CD8+ response.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The impact of variant peptides in an IFN-γ secretion assay was determined. This variant had no impact on IFN-γ secretion compared to the wild-type sequence.
The impact of variant peptides in a cytotoxicity assay was determined. This epitope did not have any substantial impact on cytotoxicity compared with the wild-type sequence.

B-cells were transfected with mRNA derived from the acute prototype (genotype 1a HCV acute infected patient) and variant sequences to assess the impact of mutations on processing and presentation of epitope. This variant sequence gave 1.8% CD8 tet+ cells releasing IFN-γ compared to the acute prototype sequence which gave 16% and mock negative control producing 1.25%.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: HLA-B8 restricted epitope. This is a naturally occuring variant identified in HCV patient with acute stage of disease after primary CD8+ response.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The impact of variant peptides in an IFN-γ secretion assay was determined. This variant had no substantial impact on IFN-γ release compared to the wild-type sequence.
The impact of variant peptides in a cytotoxicity assay was determined. This variant had no substantial impact on cytotoxicity compared to wild-type sequence.

B-cells were transfected with mRNA derived from the acute prototype (genotype 1a HCV acute infected patient) and variant sequences to assess the impact of mutations on processing and presentation of epitope. This variant sequence gave 1.9% CD8 tet+ cells releasing IFN-γ compared to the acute prototype sequence which gave 16% and mock negative control producing 1.25%.

The impact of variant peptides in an IFN-γ secretion assay was determined. This variant, which was the most frequently detected variant in chronic subjects, was less efficient at stimulation of IFN-γ release than the wild-type.

The impact of variant peptides in an IFN-γ secretion assay was determined. This variant, which was the first variant to emerge in subject 99B, was less efficient at stimulation of IFN-γ release as compared to the wild-type.
